title: Why do economists so dislike "conditional independence"?

last_post.content: Interesting post by Scott Cunningham on how conditional independence goes against rationality (people choosing the treatment based on expected benefits) and that's why economists don't like this assumption: https://causalinf.substack.com/p/why-do-economists-so-dislike-conditional Perhaps a corollary might be that selection on observables then becomes more plausible when the "treatment" is not something you choose based on a rational calculation but instead is something like a feeling or a personality trait or some aspect of your environment.

title: GitHub - jart/sectorlisp: Bootstrapping LISP in a Boot Sector

last_post.content:
I was looking at the 'Blinkenlights' project by Justine Tunney which is "a virtual machine that runs statically-compiled x86-64-linux programs on different operating systems and hardware architectures" (might as well let Justine describe it!) motivated by research on APE ("Actually Portable Executable")¹ ². #ActuallyPortableExecutable

After appreciating blink I looked at Justine's other repos, as one does, and… here's what I already bookmarked:

* "sectorlisp is a 512-byte implementation of LISP that's able to bootstrap John McCarthy's meta-circular evaluator on bare metal." - https://github.com/jart/sectorlisp #Lisp

* "Cosmopolitan Libc makes C a build-once run-anywhere language, like Java, except it doesn't need an interpreter or virtual machine. Instead, it reconfigures stock GCC and Clang to output a POSIX-approved polyglot format that runs natively on Linux + Mac + Windows + FreeBSD + OpenBSD + NetBSD + BIOS with the best possible performance and the tiniest footprint imaginable." - https://github.com/jart/cosmopolitan #Libc #VirtualMachine #Polyglot (you should also look at the work by @Ange on the vast subject of polyglots)

* "Disaster lets you press C-c d to see the compiled assembly code for the C, C++ or Fortran file you're currently editing. It even jumps to and highlights the line of assembly corresponding to the line beneath your cursor." - https://github.com/jart/disaster #Emacs #EmacsLisp #Disassembler ( @anticomputer this one is for you…)

No apologies for sending you down this Github hole :flan_molotov:​ as it is more fun to go spelunking with friends!

__
¹ https://justine.lol/ape.html
² https://github.com/jart/blink

The authors propose a simple single-neuron model where the dendrite is implemented as a sequence of thresholded linear units. They manipulate the underlying architecture and investigate the impacts of binary branching constraints and repetition of synaptic inputs on neural computation, finding that models with such manipulations can perform (surprisingly?) well on machine learning tasks.

#Neuroscience #BioInspiredComputing #MachineLearning @neuroscience

title: Genomics and phenomics of body mass index reveals a complex disease network - Nature Communications

Obesity (as measured by BMI) is linked to many health problems that can be fatal. Using a genetic risk score including 2,446 variants, obesity was found to increase the risk of 316 different diseases, being connected to a variety of health problems in the circulatory, genitourinary, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and dermatologic systems.

#NetworkMedicine #ComplexSystems #SystemsMedicine

title: Might be a good idea to limit number of followers to like 10K or 20K · Issue #20089 · mastodon/mastodon

last_post.content:
@ct_bergstrom I’ve thought a bunch about this issue of scaling, not just from the point of view of the people with big accounts, but also what it means for information flow when you have a system with this kind of power-law distribution of follower numbers.

I was actually concerned enough about it that back in November I submitted a pull request to the Mastodon GitHub suggesting that it be possible to limit follower counts. I was thoroughly hammered, partly for good reason (while few argued against my reasoning, there were a bunch of issues with actually being able to implement it that I hadn’t realised).

Despite the hammering, I still think scaling is a huge problem and is probably a lot of where some of the worst properties of modern information systems come from (e.g. I think it makes polarisation much more likely). Your suggestion of making a distinction between social systems (which don’t scale well) and broadcast (which might) is interesting. I’ll have to think about it more.

In any case, if you’re curious, I’ve linked to my GitHub request below. If you ignore all the people telling me I’m an idiot :) you might be interested in the reasoning behind my request, as it goes into a lot more depth about why I think the problem of scale is such a big one. Has some of the same points as yours, but some pretty different.

https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/issues/20089#issuecomment-1306654133
